column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a female who used Rogaine to replace some frontal hair loss due to my blood pressure medication. The product did work with hair growth after a month's or so use, so it was effective. First I will say that the solution is syrupy, and makes the hair somewhat sticky, making hair styling difficult. But more importantly, I had bad side effcts, and had to totally stop after a year of off-and-on use. 30 minutes after application I frequently had anxiety attacks and a feeling of unwellness, which would last at least a day, and would occur again during my every other day applications. After almost the year's use I developed mild dizziness(reeling) every time I changed the plane of my head, and later developed ringing in the ears. I obviously stopped totally after my hearing was affected, but the ear ringing became permanent. I noticed that besides the Minoxidil, a Rogaine solution base ingredient was propylene glycol, a cousin of anti-freeze's ethylene glycol, also a syrupy sticky liquid. I figured this chemical was absorbed through my scalp, and poisoned me. My mother, who also had hair loss due to blood pressure medication, also had the same ill-feeling symptoms. But she quit early because of them; I was more determined, and continued its use until the final inner ear problems occurred. I do not know whether others have had this experience; but for me, Rogaine is a poison.
